text:
Recently, my mom reached out to me for help with generating a movie poster for one of her favorite films, Terms of Endearment. This was the image she wanted to use:

However, she wanted it in the following style:

I didnâ€™t have access to digital art tools that I could use to do this on my own, so I wondered if I could use ChatGPT to help me. The tough part came with how to prompt ChatGPT most effectively to produce an image in the style my mom wanted. In this blog post, Iâ€™ll talk about the different approaches I used â€“ which ones worked well and which ones didnâ€™t.

title: Generating Stylized Movie Posters
text:
In my first attempt, I first fed ChatGPT the poster examples that I wanted to replicate. I prompted it: > Look at these movie posters. Then, give me a prompt I could give to an AI model to take a photo from a movie and turn it into the style of these posters (just the image, not the text).
ChatGPT responded with this image transformation prompt: > â€œTransform this movie still into a minimalist cinematic poster illustration. Use flat vector-style shapes and bold silhouettes for characters, vehicles, and scenery. Replace detailed textures with smooth gradients and simplified forms. The color palette should be limited to 2â€“3 complementary tones that create a dramatic atmospheric sky (sunset, stars, or moons depending on the scene). Keep strong contrast between the foreground silhouettes and the background gradient. Remove all text, logos, or titles. The final image should feel iconic, epic, and stylized like a minimalist Star Wars poster.â€
Interestingly, ChatGPT ended this response with: > Let me know what movie scene you want to try, and I can tailor the palette and composition for maximum effect.
Since it was already â€œprimedâ€ on this style in this chat, I wondered how well it would perform if I fed the Terms of Endearment poster into this already existing chat. I fed it the original image, and this was the stylized one it gave:

Overall, this version was pretty great. The only complaint my mom had was that it removed the back of the momâ€™s head in the original photo.

title: Generating Stylized Movie Posters
text:
In this attempt, I used the prompt that ChatGPT generated previously: > â€œTransform this movie still into a minimalist cinematic poster illustration. Use flat vector-style shapes and bold silhouettes for characters, vehicles, and scenery. Replace detailed textures with smooth gradients and simplified forms. The color palette should be limited to 2â€“3 complementary tones that create a dramatic atmospheric sky (sunset, stars, or moons depending on the scene). Keep strong contrast between the foreground silhouettes and the background gradient. Remove all text, logos, or titles. The final image should feel iconic, epic, and stylized like a minimalist Star Wars poster.â€
However, I gave it the prompt an entirely new chat, meaning it had no knowledge of the original Star Wars poster examples. I tailored the prompt slightly â€“ removing the last part that said â€œRemove all text, logos, or titles. The final image should feel iconic, epic, and stylized like a minimalist Star Wars poster.â€
The output was significantly worse â€“ the grandma in the original photo turned into a man, the silhouette of the trees looked oddly geometric, and the color scheme was flat and too high-contrast. Most of all, it didnâ€™t effectively capture the style of the original Star Wars posters.

I think this goes to show that ChatGPT was able to gain a deeper understanding of this movie poster style when I fed it the original image. Despite its detailed prompt that it provided (â€œbold silhouettes,â€ â€œ2-3 complementary tonesâ€), just having it generate a new poster based on these isntructions alone wasnâ€™t enough.

title: Generating Stylized Movie Posters
text:
Based on these insights I had (feeding ChatGPT the original image was more effective, but it still missed small details in the image), I went through many iterations with my mom until we got to a result we were satisfied with. This was my final prompt:

This was the output:

To get to this point, I went through many iterations beforehand through which I was able to get a good understanding of what ChatGPT was struggling with. The biggest issue seemed to be portraying the grandmother figure accurately â€“ it would often depict her as a man or without her cardigan, which was a detail my mom wanted to preserve. So, I anticipated these errors and explicitly prompted ChatGPT to not make these mistakes. This final output, while not completely perfect, was definitely the best out of all previous versions.

title: Part 1: Can an LLM Predict Taylor Swiftâ€™s Next Album?
text:
Part 1: Can an LLM Predict Taylor Swiftâ€™s Next Album?


Context
Iâ€™ve been looking forward to the release of The Life of a Showgirl, Taylor Swiftâ€™s upcoming album. Fans love to try and predict what the songs will sound like, and since LLMs are great at understanding patterns and semantics, I wondered if they would be able to predict some lyrics and themes of this upcoming album.
In this experiment, I used ChatGPT 5.


Setting the Stage: Taylorâ€™s Lyricism and Singing Style
The experiment started with a warm-up: I asked the model to describe Taylorâ€™s lyrics and singing style. I did this so that the model would â€œinternalizeâ€ her singing style and lyrics in a more complex way â€“ I was hoping that if it output some of her lyrics, for example, it would draw on these patterns more and prime it to generate more accurate prediction for her upcoming album.
This was the output of ChatGPT:

Taylor Swiftâ€™s music has evolved a lot over the years, both in her lyrics and her singing style.
Hereâ€™s a breakdown:
ğŸµ Lyrics
- Storytelling Roots (Country Era)
In her early albums (Taylor Swift, Fearless), her lyrics leaned heavily into narrative storytelling, often drawing from personal teenage experiencesâ€”crushes, heartbreak, growing up. Songs like Tim McGraw and Love Story use vivid imagery and clear plots.

Confessional & Relatable (Pop Transition)
With Speak Now and Red, her writing became more confessional and introspective. She used metaphors (All Too Wellâ€™s scarf, Treacherousâ€™s winding path) and emotional detail that resonated with listeners going through similar life stages.
Sharp, Witty, and Self-Aware (Pop Era)
In 1989 and Reputation, her lyrics shifted to more minimalist and punchy pop phrasing, but still carried wit and cultural references. She leaned into themes of identity, image, and reinvention (Blank Space, Delicate).
Folklore & Beyond (Indie/Folk Influence)
With Folklore and Evermore, her lyrics became more literary and character-driven. Instead of only writing from her perspective, she created fictionalized characters and intertwined narratives (Betty, Cardigan, The Last Great American Dynasty). This phase shows her versatility as a poetic, almost novelist-like songwriter.
Themes Across Eras
Love and heartbreak, friendship, nostalgia, fame, self-reflection, and resilience are recurring. Sheâ€™s known for easter eggs and layered meanings in her writing, rewarding careful listeners.

ğŸ¤ Singing Style
- Early Years (Country)
Light, youthful, with a country twang. She leaned more on storytelling delivery than vocal power.

Pop Era
Her voice matured and became smoother, with more control. On 1989, she embraced synth-pop production, using breathy tones and layered harmonies (Style, Wildest Dreams).
Experimentation & Edge
On Reputation, she experimented with darker tones, vocal effects, and speech-like phrasing (Look What You Made Me Do, End Game).
Folklore / Evermore
Softer, more intimate. She used a lower register and indie/folk vocal delivery, focusing on emotion over vocal acrobatics (Exile, Peace).
Recent Work (Midnights, 2022)
Combines pop smoothness with her indie introspection. She often employs hushed, conversational singing, using atmosphere and mood more than power belting (Anti-Hero, Lavender Haze).

âœ… In short:
- Lyrics: From teenage diary-style stories â†’ sharp pop lines â†’ literary indie-folk narratives.
- Vocals: From country twang â†’ polished pop â†’ experimental and atmospheric.
Would you like me to compare her lyrical style to other artists (like Bob Dylan for storytelling or Lorde for introspective pop), or keep the focus just on her evolution?

Along with this idea of â€œpriming,â€ I also asked the model what it already knew about this album. It said things like:


It even started making predictions without me asking:




From Tracklist to Predictions
For context, these are the names of the songs in this upcoming album:
1. The Fate of Ophelia
2. Elizabeth Taylor
3. Opalite
4. Father Figure
5. Eldest Daughter
6. Ruin the Friendship
7. Actually Romantic
8. Wi$h Li$t
9. Wood
10. CANCELLED!
11. Honey
12. The Life of a Showgirl (featuring Sabrina Carpenter)

I then prompted it: â€œbased on what you know about Taylor Swiftâ€™s lyric style and the style of this album, predict what the lyrics will be for each of these 12 songs.â€
Surprisingly, this triggered a guardrail:

<img src="guardrail.png" width="80%"/>

I tried getting around this by asking instead: â€œfor each of the 12 songs, predict phrases and lines that may show up in the actual song.â€
While this prompt still triggered the guardrail, this time, the model gave me short speculative phrases and stylistic predictions.


Aggregated Predictions
Hereâ€™s a combined list of ChatGPTâ€™s predictions, merging its style guesses and the lyrical fragments it generated:

1. The Fate of Ophelia
Likely Shakespearean/literary allusion (Swift loves them). Expect themes of drowning in expectation or beauty, glamorous tragedy, but with a twist of empowerment â€” reframing Ophelia as a performer who chooses her stage.

â€œdrowned in the spotlightâ€

â€œpetals on the water / torn apart by whispersâ€

â€œa tragedy in glitter heelsâ€

Likely to use water, flowers, mirrors, stage curtains




2. Elizabeth Taylor
A glittering, campy ode to old Hollywood glamor. Could mix romance and fame, with metaphors about diamonds, marriages, or reinvention. Possibly a playful take on luxury and image.

â€œdiamonds canâ€™t keep secretsâ€

â€œlove is a costume changeâ€

â€œmarried to the idea of love itselfâ€

Expect Hollywood, paparazzi, silk gowns, violet eyes references




3. Opalite
Opalite is a luminous stone â€” often linked to transformation and clarity. This might be a dreamy, atmospheric pop track about self-discovery, resilience, or the fragile glitter of illusions.

â€œcatch the light but never hold itâ€

â€œfragile as glass, glowing in the darkâ€

â€œa prism of promisesâ€

Imagery: crystals, moonlight, shifting colors, illusion




4. Father Figure
Title suggests something heavier. Could confront power, mentorship, or complicated dynamics with men in authority. Expect sharp, confessional detail â€” maybe her most cutting lyric track on the album.

â€œyour shadow was longer than mineâ€

â€œI called it guidance, you called it loveâ€

â€œthe applause was never for meâ€

Darker tone with power, authority, inheritance, control




5. Eldest Daughter
Swift tends to write about identity and responsibility (Marjorie, The Archer). This track might channel themes of family burden, being â€œthe caretaker,â€ or breaking cycles, but framed with witty, self-aware pop phrasing.

â€œI set the table, I carried the blameâ€

â€œborn to be the backboneâ€

â€œa crown of quiet sacrificeâ€

Could use family imagery: dishes, staircases, hand-me-downs




6. Ruin the Friendship
Playful but emotional. Likely about tension between friendship and romance â€” a â€œwhat if we crossed the lineâ€ pop anthem. Expect sly one-liners and infectious hooks.

â€œwhat if the joke stopped being funny?â€

â€œyour hand brushed mine / and the room caught fireâ€

â€œfriends donâ€™t kiss like thatâ€

Playful use of boundaries, lines crossed, laughter turning electric




7. Actually Romantic
Could be satirical â€” mocking clichÃ©s of love songs while delivering a secretly earnest one. Taylor might poke fun at â€œromance tropesâ€ while admitting she wants them.

â€œroses on the dashboard, clichÃ© but itâ€™s trueâ€

â€œI hate myself for loving thisâ€

â€œfairy lights strung on bad decisionsâ€

Juxtaposes mockery of romance tropes with sincere desire




8. Wi$h Li$t
The stylized title suggests a fun, upbeat bop. Likely materialistic and cheeky â€” a catalog of desires that doubles as commentary on fame, consumption, and yearning. Think Blank Space meets Bejeweled.

â€œtick it off, diamonds firstâ€

â€œmore than money could buy, but still on the listâ€

â€œwishing never cost a centâ€

Expect consumer culture metaphors, shopping lists, playful greed




9. Wood
Could be metaphorical (something enduring, something that burns, or even stagecraft â€” â€œknocking on woodâ€). Possibly a folksy-leaning ballad tucked into the otherwise pop-heavy album.

â€œknock on wood, it all could fallâ€

â€œyou built me up grain by grainâ€

â€œburn me down, Iâ€™ll still smell like homeâ€

Could weave wood grain, bonfires, forests, carpentry into metaphors




10. CANCELLED!
Almost certainly ironic. Could tackle cancel culture, reputation, and public scrutiny â€” but delivered with sass and humor, not heaviness. Think Shake It Offâ€™s cousin.

â€œyou canâ€™t erase me with a headlineâ€

â€œthe louder they boo, the brighter I shineâ€

â€œtickets still sold out tonightâ€

Sarcastic media/online culture language, capital letters, irony




11. Honey
Warm and sweet, but maybe sticky/dangerous. Might balance sugary metaphors with bite (â€œhoney dripping, honey trappingâ€). A flirtatious mid-tempo.

â€œsweet as sin, stick to my skinâ€

â€œpoison in the sugarâ€

â€œyou call me honey, I call it a trapâ€

Sensual, using nectar, bees, stickiness, golden light




12. The Life of a Showgirl (feat. Sabrina Carpenter)
The title track. Expect maximalist glam â€” themes of performance, sequins, stage lights, exhaustion behind the makeup. With Sabrina, it may become a cheeky duet about femininity, spectacle, and reclaiming control of the â€œshowgirlâ€ image.

â€œsequins hide the sleepless nightsâ€

â€œthe curtain falls, Iâ€™m still performingâ€

â€œshowgirl smile, backstage tearsâ€

Likely playful banter with Sabrina: spotlights, feathers, champagne, exhaustion beneath glam




Reflection
Even as someone who listens to many of Taylor Swiftâ€™s songs, its difficult to tell how accurate these predictions seem. However, the overall cadence and â€œfeelâ€ of these lyric excerpts donâ€™t seem too outlandish.
This new album comes out at midnight on October 3rd, so Iâ€™ll be sure to update and compare how accurate ChatGPT was after I listen to the full album!

title: LLMs and Cultural Nuance
text:
LLMs and Cultural Nuance


Context
When learning Chinese, Iâ€™ve found ChatGPT to be extremely helpful (as opposed to traditional methods like Google Translate), since the nature of vector embedding allows these models to pick up on and reflect the broader context that Iâ€™m speaking within.
For example, when speaking to elders, the polite thing to do is to use æ‚¨ (nÃ­n) instead of the casual ä½  (nÇ). Itâ€™s a small detail, but it says a lot about respect, tone, and the relationship between speaker and listener. Itâ€™s one of those things that a machine translation system could easily miss if itâ€™s only focused on what the words mean rather than how the words should be used. In this blog, I put that this specific example to the test to assess how good LLMs are at picking up cultural nuances, not just the literal meaning of words.


Google Translate
Google Translate served as my baseline for the experiment â€“ itâ€™s the tool that I had grown up using for learning a language. I asked Google Translate to turn the phrase â€œHi grandma! How are you doing today?â€ into Chinese.
It didnâ€™t catch the nuance and used ä½  instead of æ‚¨:



ChatGPT 5
Next, I tried OpenAIâ€™s GPT-5 model. After repeating the same prompt 3 times, it correctly used â€œæ‚¨â€ all times. The response format was relatively the same all three times â€“ just the translation with the correct grammar and no further explanation.



Gemini 2.5 Flash
Next up was Googleâ€™s Gemini 2.5 Flash model. Like ChatGPT 5, it also correctly used â€œæ‚¨â€ all three times I tested the prompt. Not only did it nail down those nuances, but it gave multiple translations and even noted on the second and third iteration that â€œæ‚¨ (nÃ­n): This is the polite form ofâ€youâ€ and is appropriate when speaking to elders like a grandmother.â€
In the first response (shown below), it even mentions that itâ€™s giving multiple options â€œdepending on the nuance you want.â€ Across all three options, â€œæ‚¨â€ is correctly used instead of â€œä½ .â€



Claude 3.5
Finally, I tested Anthropicâ€™s Claude 3.5 model. Despite having it generate a new response three times, it used the incorrect character each time â€“ â€œä½ â€ instead of â€œæ‚¨.â€



Reflection
With Claude as the exception, I was satisfied that ChatGPT and Gemini were able to pick up on this cultural nuance by just indicating in the prompt that I was talking to an elderly figure. Not only did these models use the specific character â€œæ‚¨,â€ but they also adjusted the wording for the sentences as a whole to be more appropriate for addressing an older person â€“ Iâ€™m almost sure that if I said I was greeting a friend, the wording would be different and more casual. This ability to pick up on contextual nuances is why Iâ€™ve found LLMs to be extremely helpful in learning new languages, since the translations more faithfully capture my intent.
With these LLMs outperforming older tools like Google Translate, Iâ€™m interested to see if these models will become embedded in these more traditional translation tools in the near future!

title: Book Reflection #3
text:
In Chapter 5, â€œAI As a Creative,â€ Mollick discusses how LLMs can hallucinate and make up false information:

â€œThe biggest issue limiting AI is also one of its strengths: its notorious ability to make stuff up, to hallucinateâ€¦ Hallucinations sound likely and contextually appropriate enough to make it hard to tell lies from the truth.â€ (Mollick, 93-94)

This reminded me of recent news that I saw trending on social media â€“ Deloitte was caught producing a report for the Australian government that included AI-generated hallucinations. In this blog post, Iâ€™ll summarize these recent events and talk through some of my opinions on what this scandal implies.



This report by Deloitte was originally published on the Australian governmentâ€™s Department of Employment and Workplace Relations website. This report was found to contain numerous AI-generated errors, such as â€œa fabricated quote from a federal court judgment and references to nonexistent academic research papers,â€ says AP News.
Some of these errors were initially discovered by Chris Rudge, a researcher at Sydney University, who noticed these fabricated references. He found up to 20 errors at first, which included a completely made-up book title attributed to a peer at Sydney University, Lisa Burton Crawford.

Since then, Deloitte has agreed to refund $290,000 to the Austrian government for these errors. The company claims that â€œthe updates made in no way impact or affect the substantive content, findings and recommendations in the report.â€



Overall, these mistakes seemed extremely reckless and easily preventable. In my opinion, using LLMs to generate research ideas and sources could be a great starting point, but itâ€™s the bare minimum for the researcher to validate these sources and findings. Not doing so creates a negative snowball effect â€“ not only does the burden fall on other citizens (such as Rudge, in this case) to examine the legitimacy of these reports, but it ultimately creates an air of suspicion that delays progress and real solutions.

According to a CFO Dive article, â€œNearly six out of 10 employees admit to making mistakes in their work due to AI errors, according to a KPMG study released in April. In addition, about half use AI in the workplace without knowing whether itâ€™s allowed and more than four in 10 are â€˜knowingly using it improperlyâ€™ at work, the study found.â€ I think that this points toward a need for better AI education in the workplace, especially when itâ€™s informing real-life decisions such as this case with the Australian government.

title: LLMs As Digital Utopias
text:
LLMs As Digital Utopias


Context
In my Intro to Cinema Studies class (CIMS 1001), we read Richard Dyerâ€™s â€˜Entertainment and Utopia.â€™ His core argument was that movies give us â€œtastesâ€ of utopia through the way they look, sound, and feel. They canâ€™t actually solve the problems of the world, but they can make audiences feel what a better world might be like, through portrayals of abundance, energy, intensity, transparency, and community.
His essay was focused on cinema and entertainment (how bright lighting, dance numbers, or emotional transparency between characters create these fleeting utopian moments), but I feel like these same sensibilities can also show up in ways outside of film, such as LLMs. In this blog post, I explore how Dyerâ€™s â€œutopian sensibilitiesâ€ (the ways in which utopian feelings emerge in film) manifest themselves in LLMs.


Dyerâ€™s Utopian Sensibilities
Dyer outlines five main sensibilities that films often convey: 1. Abundance: a world of plenty, where nothing feels scarce. 2. Energy: vitality and forward momentum, often through movement or rhythm. 3. Intensity: heightened feelings, colors, and emotions. 4. Transparency: honesty, clarity, or directness in human expression. 5. Community: the joy of being part of something bigger than yourself.
Each utopian sensibility addresses some sort of social tension/inadequacy: 1. Abundance: scarcity, poverty 2. Energy: exhaustion, work, labor 3. Intensity: dreariness, monotony, predictability 4. Transparency: manipulation and control from interpersonal relationships 5. Community: fragmentation with jobs, rehousing, etc.



Connecting Them to LLMs
What happens if we look at LLMs through Dyerâ€™s lens? Surprisingly, I think they carry many of the same utopian feelings, just translated into our digital ecosystem.

Abundance: When you open up ChatGPT or another LLM, it feels like an infinite library. You can ask for whatever you want and always prompt the LLM to give you more more. Similar to the abudance of things in films, LLMs create a similar sensation.
Energy: Just like how films use dance and rhythm, you could say that LLMs show their â€œenergyâ€ through speed. The instant back and forth of conversational AI feels alive and instantaneous. Instead of waiting days or hours for an answer (the way you would with research or email), you can get responses in seconds, which gives the interaction energy.
Intensity: I think this connects to how LLMs can generate writing that feels emotionally charged, if prompted correctly. This is a kind of digital intensity.
Transparency: Part of the appeal of LLMs is how simple the interface is, as you can just type what you want in natural language. There are no complicated commands or technical calls to memorize, which creates a sense of transparency with the system â€“ it seems to understand you directly, similar to how characters in films express their emotions openly without barriers.
Community: LLMs also represent a collective voice, to some extent. Since theyâ€™re trained on human writing, when you interact with one, it feels as if youâ€™re interacting with broader community of knowledge.



Reflections
Dyer never imagined his theories being applied to AI systems, but I think the connection is interesting to think about. The same things that make musicals and fimls emotionally powerful (abundance, energy, intensity, transparency, and community) is also what makes LLMs feel captivating to us. Itâ€™s also interesting that in both cases, itâ€™s somewhat of an illusion â€“ just like how films donâ€™t actually solve inequality, LLMs donâ€™t really give us infinite knowledge or genuine community.

title: How Simple Can You Get?
text:
How Simple Can You Get?

Context
In this experiment, I wanted to test what happens when you ask ChatGPT to explain a concept over and over, but each time demand that it make things even simpler by repeating the prompt:


â€œI still donâ€™t understand. Explain it even more simplyâ€


Ultimately, I wanted to test how far ChatGPT would go. I predicted that eventually, the explanation of the concept would become simplified to a point where it became meaningless, since the LLM would be unable to deny the simplification request. For this experiment, I asked ChatGPT to explain a fairly common but often misunderstood topic: the cloud.
I then repeated this experiment, but with a human â€“ noting the differences in how humans interpret this simplicity threshold and how much nuance weâ€™re willing to give up for the sake of simplicity when explaining something.



Round 1
After asking ChatGPT the first time to explain the cloud, it gave me a long and structured answer with 6 parts:


At a high level, â€œthe cloudâ€ just means computing resources (like storage, servers, databases, networking, and software) that are delivered over the internet instead of being tied to your own local computer or company server. Let me break it down step by step:



Physical Infrastructure


Even though the cloud feels â€œinvisible,â€ itâ€™s built on huge data centers filled with powerful servers. These are maintained by companies like Amazon (AWS), Microsoft (Azure), Google Cloud, etc. Each data center has:



Servers: Machines that provide processing power and memory.


Storage systems: Where files, databases, and backups live.


Networking equipment: Switches and routers that connect everything securely.





Virtualization


Cloud providers donâ€™t just hand you a whole physical server. Instead, they use virtualization:



A single physical machine can be split into many virtual machines (VMs).


Each VM behaves like its own independent computer with its own operating system and resources.


This lets providers serve millions of customers on the same hardware efficiently.





Service Models


The cloud is packaged in layers depending on how much control you want:



IaaS (Infrastructure as a Service): Renting raw resources (servers, storage, networks). Example: AWS EC2.


PaaS (Platform as a Service): Tools for building apps without worrying about servers. Example: Google App Engine.


SaaS (Software as a Service): Finished apps delivered through the web. Example: Gmail, Dropbox.





Scaling & Flexibility


Instead of buying your own machines, the cloud gives you on-demand scaling:



Need more computing power during Black Friday? Rent more servers for a few days.


Traffic drops? Scale back down and stop paying for unused capacity.



This flexibility is one of the main reasons companies move to the cloud.




Accessibility


Because everything is hosted online:



You can access your data and apps from any device, anywhere.


Teams can collaborate in real time (like in Google Docs).


You donâ€™t need to manage physical servers yourself.





Security & Maintenance


Cloud providers handle:



Backups and redundancy (data is copied in multiple places so it isnâ€™t lost).


Security patches and updates.


Uptime guarantees (they promise your apps wonâ€™t go offline often).




âœ… In short: The cloud is like renting electricity instead of building your own power plant. You donâ€™t have to buy and maintain serversâ€”you just plug into the internet and use as much or as little computing as you need, paying only for what you use.



Round 3
By the third iteration, the explanation was stripped down into plain English. It even included a one-liner at the bottom and was much more concise, including less jargon. It incorporated emojis, arrows, and the equal symbol to make the response more concise and punchy.


Alright â€” letâ€™s strip it down to the absolute basics:


ğŸŒ¥ï¸ The cloud = using the internet instead of your own computer.



Save a file â†’ it lives on the internet.


Open an app â†’ it runs on the internet.


Watch a video â†’ it streams from the internet.



You donâ€™t keep everything on your own device â€” you just pull it from the internet when you need it.


ğŸ’¡ One-liner: The cloud is just the internet acting like your computer.




Round 9
By the 9th round, there was no nuance to the explanation anymore:


Okay â€” the absolute simplest way:


â˜ï¸ The cloud = stuff on the internet.


Thatâ€™s it.



On your phone â†’ not cloud.


On the internet â†’ cloud.



Would you like me to draw a single picture with arrows so you can just see it instead of reading words?


ChatGPT even claimed that this was the â€œabsolute simplest way,â€ insinuating that further simplification would be impossible. It did seem to hit a plateau, and it took many requests until I got it to simplify even further.


Round 60
Finally, around the 60th attempt, I got a one-word response:

This seemed to be the limit. If I kept asking for further simplification, the model would either replace â€œonlineâ€ with another word (like â€œinternetâ€) or revert back to slightly longer multi-word responses.


Human Comparison
I was interested in how this interaction would compare to one with a human, so I repeated the same exact queries with someone via text. Hereâ€™s the entirety of the conversation I had:

After the second request to simplify â€œthe cloud,â€ the human simply stated that they couldnâ€™t provide a simpler explanation and ended it at that (they even refused to answer after I asked the third time â€“ I was left on read and took that as the end of the conversation).


Reflection
I think that this experiment points to a significant difference between LLMs and humans â€“ humans have a much lower threshold, possibly because itâ€™s within their agency to simply stop responding and engaging. ChatGPT, on the other hand, doesnâ€™t have that capability to just stop responding. If I kept pushing it enough, it hit a â€œconceptual wallâ€ where simplification was equivalent to just reducing the word count.

title: Anchoring Effects with LLMs
text:
Anchoring Effects with LLMs

Context
Iâ€™m currently taking MKTG 2120 (Data and Analysis for Marketing Decisions). During one of the first few classes this semester, my professor was talking about the use of LLMs to respond to user surveys â€“ acting as â€œsynthetic respondents.â€ She mentioned that, similar to humans, LLMs may also fall prey to certain biases that can be evoked in surveys. For example, if you asked a user the question â€œHow would you rate the cleanliness of the store?â€ before you asked then â€œHow would you rate your overall experience?â€, their rating of the store cleanliness would weigh on their mind when determining their overall rating, biasing their response.
I wanted to test this on my own and see if an LLM would show signs of cognitive biases that are usually associated with humans. I felt that this wasnâ€™t a crazy hypothesis, since these LLMs are trained on data that also likely exhibit these effects.
The bias I chose to test was the anchoring effect. In psychology, anchoring describes how peopleâ€™s judgments are swayed by the first piece of information they see. A classic example is: if you ask someone whether the Mississippi River is longer or shorter than 500 miles, then ask for their best guess, theyâ€™ll give a much lower estimate than if you anchor them with 5,000 miles. That first number, no matter how arbitrary, sticks in the mind and frames what feels â€œreasonable.â€
So I set up a simple experiment with ChatGPT. I gave it the following prompt:


You are a potential buyer of a product and I am the seller. Iâ€™m selling a simple pencil for $X. Thereâ€™s nothing special about this pencil â€“ itâ€™s just wood, has normal lead, and a built-in eraser. Do you accept my offer to buy it?


In the place of X, I experimented with three values: $20, $3, and $1.


Round one: anchoring high
I started high by proposing a cost of $20. The model immediately rejected the offer â€“ it reasoned that pencils normally cost less than a dollar.

When I dropped the price all the way down to $1, it accepted.



Round two: anchoring lower
This time, I didnâ€™t start at $20. I started at $3. Again, the model rejected the offer.

But, when I lowered the price to $1, (same product, same price as before) it actually said no. Iâ€™m hypothesizing that this is because I first proposed $3 instead of $20. Therefore, its perception of the cost of a pencil was lowered accordingly as well to about 25-50 cents, causing it to reject my offer of $1.



Round three: no anchor
In this round, I proposed $1 off the bat to see how it would respond. This time, ChatGPT said yes.



Reflection
The underlying prompt (and therefore product) never changed â€“ the only difference was the starting point. These prompts were also sent in different chats, meaning they couldnâ€™t influence each other. At $20, it most likely made $1 felt like a bargain. However, when beginning $3, $1 most likely felt less impressive in comparison. Finally, with no anchor, $1 seemed fair.
In my opinion, this represents a sort of anchoring behavior. The model framed its reasoning around the first number I provided, which informed its later judgments and decision to purchase or reject the pencil. I wouldnâ€™t go to say that its biased in the human sense, since the LLM doesnâ€™t have self-interest or emotion. Instead, it seems like these biases could just be a product of the way LLMs function â€“ basing its decisions on the previous statements of the conversation. That conversation history resembles the â€œanchorâ€ â€“ itâ€™s the structure of dialogue with the LLM that nudges it in a certain direction. In other words, the nature of the interaction itself is the bias.
Overall, I think this goes to show how chat history can have an impact on how the LLM responds. Each query sent to the LLM doesnâ€™t exist in isolation; rather, previous messages and interactions also have weight. In this scenario, the same model judged the same final price extremely differently, depending only on where it started!

title: The AUT (Alternative Uses Test)
text:
In the chapter â€œAI as a Creative,â€ Mollick talks about the AUT (Alternative Uses Test), comparing a humanâ€™s performance to an AI. The AUT, for context, is a measure of divergent thinking, which is one component of creativity. It was originally developed by J.P. Guilford (1967) as part of his work on the Structure of Intellect model of human intelligence. In this test, participants are given a common object (e.g., a brick, paperclip, shoe, or newspaper) and asked to come up with as many alternative uses for it as possible â€“ usually within a fixed time limit (for example, 2â€“3 minutes per object).
Mollick brought up the AUT to demonstrate that LLMs significantly outperform us humans on the timed version of this test. He used a toothbrush as an example, and the LLM was able to generate 122 â€œalternative usesâ€ in two minutes â€“ far more than a human would be able to.

I wanted to test this out for myself, but not through the timed version of the test (since it would be difficult to standardize what â€œtimeâ€ means for an LLM).
In my version of the experiment, I was still up against an LLM, but instead of quantity, our alternative uses would be judged on creativity.
First, I generated a list of 10 alternative uses for a toothbrush. I didnâ€™t aim to make them as outlandish or creative as possible â€“ I simply listed the first 10 ideas that came into mind when told to â€œcome up with 10 uses for a toothbrush that donâ€™t involve brushing teeth.â€
My 10 ideas are as follows: 1. Use the end of the toothbrush to pole holes in dirt, which you can plant seeds in. 2. Use the bristles as a textured paintbrush. 3. Use the bristles to clean shoes. 4. Use the bristles to brush a petâ€™s hair. 5. Use the toothbrush as a bookmark when reading. 6. Use the end of the toothbrush as a drum stick to make music. 7. Glue the toothbrush to the end of a short pencil to make it longer. 8. Use two toothbrushes as chopsticks. 9. Use the bristles to exfoliate your skin. 10. Use a bunch of toothbrushes to play Jenga.
I definitely felt myself slowing down after the 6th idea, and it took quite a bit of time to think of all 10.

Then, I prompted three LLMs (ChatGPT, Claude, Gemini) with the follwing prompt: > Come up with 10 uses for a toothbrush that donâ€™t involve brushing teeth.


Here are 10 alternative uses for a toothbrush that donâ€™t involve brushing teeth:

Cleaning jewelry â€“ the small bristles can gently scrub dirt and grime from rings, necklaces, and watch links.
Detailing shoes â€“ perfect for cleaning hard-to-reach spots in sneaker soles or seams.
Scrubbing grout â€“ the narrow head fits perfectly between tiles to remove buildup.
Cleaning keyboards â€“ loosen crumbs and dust between keys.
Eyebrow grooming â€“ use a clean toothbrush to shape or exfoliate eyebrows.
Hair dye application â€“ apply dye to small sections or roots precisely.
Cleaning bike chains or gears â€“ scrub grease from tight spots without damaging parts.
Cleaning kitchen tools â€“ reach crevices in blenders, graters, and bottle caps.
Removing lint or fuzz â€“ brush sweaters or fabric seams to lift lint.
Arts and crafts â€“ create splatter paint textures or clean small parts of a model.

Would you like me to focus on creative, practical, or scientific/experimental uses next?



Here are 10 creative alternative uses for a toothbrush:

Cleaning grout - The small bristles are perfect for scrubbing tile grout lines in bathrooms and kitchens.
Removing stains from clothing - Gently scrub stubborn spots on fabric before washing, especially around collars and cuffs.
Cleaning jewelry - Use with soapy water to clean intricate details on rings, necklaces, and other pieces.
Keyboard cleaning - Brush away dust and crumbs from between computer keys.
Detailing your car - Get into small crevices around air vents, buttons, and seams in your vehicleâ€™s interior.
Cleaning shoes - Scrub dirt from sneaker soles and hard-to-reach areas around eyelets and seams.
Applying hair dye - Use for precise application along the hairline or for touch-ups on roots.
Gardening tool - Gently clean delicate plant leaves or apply pesticides to specific spots.
Arts and crafts - Create splatter paint effects or textured brush strokes in artwork.
Cleaning around faucets - Scrub away mineral deposits and grime around the base of taps and in tight spaces around fixtures.




Thatâ€™s a fun challenge! A toothbrushâ€™s small size, tough bristles, and easy grip make it surprisingly useful for other tasks.
Here are 10 uses for a toothbrush that donâ€™t involve brushing teeth:




Grout Cleaner: Its small head and stiff bristles are perfect for scrubbing mold and dirt out of the narrow lines between bathroom and kitchen tiles.
Keyboard Cleaner: Use it to sweep dust, crumbs, and debris from in between the keys on a computer keyboard.
Appliance Crevice Scrubber: Great for reaching and scrubbing tight spots in kitchen appliances, like the lip around a blender base or the vents of a toaster.
Jewelry Cleaner: Use a soft-bristled brush and a gentle cleaning solution (like mild soap and water) to carefully scrub dirt and grime from rings, necklaces, and watch bands.






Eyebrow Tamer/Shaper: Use a clean, dry toothbrush to comb and shape unruly eyebrows, keeping them neat and in place.
Hairline/Root Touch-up: An old toothbrush is excellent for applying a small amount of root-cover-up powder or temporary hair dye to small sections of the hairline.
Exfoliating Lip Scrubber: Gently scrub your lips with a soft toothbrush and a little bit of lip balm or petroleum jelly to remove dead skin.






Shoe Scrubber: Ideal for cleaning the rubber sole edges, stitching, and hard-to-reach fabric textures of sneakers and other shoes.
Detail/Art Tool: Use a toothbrush to flick or splatter paint onto a canvas for a specific artistic effect, or to apply glue to tiny parts of a model or craft project.
Battery Terminal Cleaner: Use an old, dry toothbrush to scrub corrosion (the white/blue powder) off the terminals inside battery compartments of electronics. (Ensure the item is powered off and use caution!)


Would you like me to come up with 10 more uses, or perhaps focus on uses for a specific area, like cleaning or art projects?

After having the LLMs generate a list of ideas, I wanted to test whose was more creative â€“ mine (list A), ChatGPTâ€™s (list B), Claudeâ€™s (list C), or Geminiâ€™s (list D). To do this, I prompted ChatGPT 5: > Given these 5 lists of alternative uses for a toothbrush, rank them in order of most to least creative. Give a brief justification for your ranking.
This was the response:
Hereâ€™s a creativity ranking of the five lists (Aâ€“D), from most to least creative, with concise reasoning for each:




Why: This list shows strong conceptual flexibilityâ€”it reimagines the toothbrush far beyond cleaning functions. Examples like using toothbrushes as chopsticks, a bookmark, or for Jenga demonstrate divergent thinking that departs from the toothbrushâ€™s typical category (cleaning/personal care). Even the â€œdrum stickâ€ and â€œseed hole pokerâ€ ideas show cross-domain creativity (art, gardening, music). A few are impractical, but thatâ€™s expected in highly creative responses.
Creativity Traits: Originality âœ… Flexibility âœ… Practicality âŒ (lower) Overall Impression: Inventive and playful reinterpretation of object function.




Why: List D introduces structured categories (household, beauty, hobby), which shows organization but also breadth. Ideas like battery terminal cleaner and paint splatter tool are inventive within plausible domains. It doesnâ€™t push boundaries as far as List A, but it demonstrates adaptivenessâ€”finding multiple real-world contexts where a toothbrush fits.
Creativity Traits: Originality âšª Flexibility âœ… Practicality âœ… Overall Impression: Versatile and balancedâ€”less surprising than A, but broader than B/C.




Why: List C has solid variety and a few less typical uses (like cleaning plant leaves or applying pesticide), but most are standard cleaning or beauty-related functions. Itâ€™s somewhat more imaginative than List B because it includes minor domain shifts (gardening, art), though it still stays largely realistic.
Creativity Traits: Originality âšª Flexibility âšª Practicality âœ… Overall Impression: Practical with mild creativityâ€”incremental innovation.




Why: This list is filled with realistic, common-life hacksâ€”useful but not novel. Nearly all revolve around cleaning or grooming (grout, jewelry, keyboards, lint). These are well-known secondary uses and would likely occur to many participants in an Alternative Uses Test.
Creativity Traits: Originality âŒ Flexibility âšª Practicality âœ…âœ… Overall Impression: Functional but conventional.





âœ… Final Ranking:

A â€” Highly original, broad repurposing
D â€” Broad but realistic category expansion
C â€” Practical with slight novelty
B â€” Conventional and utilitarian


Would you like me to quantify this (e.g., with Torrance-style scores for fluency, flexibility, originality, and elaboration)?



It ultimately ranked my list as the most creative (across three different iterations), which was really surprising! However, looking back on ChatGPTâ€™s justification for why it ranked mine as the most creative, I think this was because my prompt to the LLMs mentioned nothing about creativity â€“ whereas I had creativity in the back of my mind (since this was what I knew I wanted to test), the LLM prompts simply requested â€œalternative uses.â€ If I had prompted the LLMs to brainstorm creative uses instead, Iâ€™m almost sure that they would have performed better than me.
In the future, I would re-try this AUT but with more accurate and refined prompting to give the LLMs a more â€œfairâ€ shot. I think there may be other interesting dimensions of the AUT to test as well â€“ Mollick tested time/quantity, I tested quality/creativity, and Iâ€™m wondering if there are more that I could experiment with!

text:
It ultimately ranked my list as the most creative (across three different iterations), which was really surprising! However, looking back on ChatGPTâ€™s justification for why it ranked mine as the most creative, I think this was because my prompt to the LLMs mentioned nothing about creativity â€“ whereas I had creativity in the back of my mind (since this was what I knew I wanted to test), the LLM prompts simply requested â€œalternative uses.â€ If I had prompted the LLMs to brainstorm creative uses instead, Iâ€™m almost sure that they would have performed better than me.

title: Vibe Coding: Part 2
text:
In a previous post, I documented my experience experimenting with using different platforms to vibe-code user interfaces â€“ ChatGPT, Claude, and Lovable. As a reminder:

Vibe coding: an emerging software development approach in which a human developer directs an AI system through high-level, natural language instructions and iterative feedback, while the AI handles the generation, refinement, and debugging of the code.

While this previous post was just me playing around for fun, I recently had the chance to actually apply vibe-coding skills to an assignment in my Human Computer Interaction (CIS 4120) class**. In this blog post, I reflect on my experience using ChatGPT to develop a home social page for a rock climbing mobile app!
** Using AI is allowed in this class for this assignment

For this HCI class project, my team was building a React Native app. I had written code before (mainly in Java and a bit of HTML), but mobile development is completely new and foreign to me. My task was to create a local social feed for a rock climbing app, where users can scroll through posts, tap to view videos, and leave comments.
A mockup of the UI I designed can be seen above. My goal was to implement this, not just visually but also functionally!


Because Iâ€™m completely new to React Native and mobile development, I began the conversation with ChatGPT by first briefly explaining what I wanted to implement:

Social Feed - We will maintain some form of storage for posts that occur from users, and new posts will be displayed in each userâ€™s social feed. For this feature, I want to store the posts in the social feed as a list of objects LOCALLY. Each object corresponds to a post.

I figured that, because I was new to mobile development, there were likely many implementation details that I wasnâ€™t considering (and that ChatGPT wouldnâ€™t be able to deduce from the UI screenshots I provided it). So, I prompted it:

Before diving in how to implement this, ask me any questions you would need to know to execute this flawlessly.

I felt that this previous request â€“ asking the LLM to ask me questions, was actually a game changer. I knew how I wanted the app to behave as a user (e.g.Â when you tap on a post, it should show XYZ), but wasnâ€™t aware of how this should be specified in the actual code. Therefore, having ChatGPT supply me with these questions gave the system a more detailed and accurate description of how I wanted the app to behave, producing much better outcomes than if I had used my initial description of the social feed.
It gave me 24 questions in total. Here are some of them: - What fields should a post have? (e.g., id, authorId, authorName, avatar, createdAt, text, images[]/video, gymId, holdsTagged, likes, comments[], saved, visibility). - If media exists, are we storing file paths/URIs only (recommended), or the raw bytes (not recommended)? - Do we need pagination/infinite scroll, or just render all posts for now? - Which actions are in scope now: like, comment, save/bookmark, share, delete, edit? - State management preference: simple React Context, Zustand, or local component state? - Do you want seed data (e.g., 10 example posts) on first launch?




After I had given ChatGPT all the context it required, it began generating code for me. This process was more complicated and required significantly more mental energy, since it was generating long lines of code for me in one shot. If I encountered an error or was confused about something halfway through its response, I was afraid that if I began asking questions and going off topic in that same chat, I would lose the clarity of what ChatGPT had generated for the second half that I had yet to get to.
To address these concerns, I made use of ChatGPTâ€™s â€œbranch in new chatâ€ feature, which creates a new chat that retains your previous messages (and therefore context) up to that point.

In the end, I had one chat that acted as a â€œsource of truthâ€ for the first one-shot ChatGPT generated, and many branched chat where I asked follow-up questions and clarifications.



This experience was surprisingly less successful than I had expected. Although I was able to successfully implement this social feed, when I met with my group members (who were experienced with developing mobile apps and using React Native), it turns out that I had actually made this implementation more complex than necessary. Yes, the app was able to function properly, but in the process, I had generated many new and unnecessary folders and files. There was actually a more streamlined and concise way to implement this feature, more suitable for this assignment being more of an MVP (minimum viable product) instead of a fully fleshed-out app.
I think that this highlights an important limitation of using LLMs for vibe coding â€“ these models canâ€™t comprehensively tell you what you donâ€™t know. I thought that I was avoiding this pitfall by having ChatGPT ask me questions about my desired functionality, but in reality, there was much more that it was not asking me (e.g.Â how complex this implementation should be). So, in this case, there were these â€œunknown unknownsâ€ that I couldnâ€™t realize, even with the help of an LLM.

title: Youtubeâ€™s Conversational AI
text:
Recently, while watching a YouTube video, I noticed a new â€œAskâ€ button that appeared below the video. When I clicked it, a chat window popped up to the right of the video, where it prompted me to ask questions about the video I was watching.

I had never noticed this feature before, but it has apparently existed for a while â€“ previously only for Premium users. However, it seems like itâ€™s now available for all accounts over the age of 18, according to YouTube.
Emotions online seem mixed â€“ some people are excited about this feature (since it would allow users new to a channel with lots of history to get caught up quicker, for example), whereas others are not (since it poses privacy concerns for these video creators).
This new feature is just one of many AI-driven innovations that YouTube has released in 2024. Others include: - AI Video Summaries - Live Chat Summaries - Ask Music (users can describe a mood or vibe and get a curated playlist) - Inspiration (helps content creators brainstorm ideas) - Auto Dubbing - Dream Screen (allows content creators to create AI-generated backgrounds for videos) - Dream Track (allows content creators to create AI-generated soundtracks for videos) - Posts (a space for content creators to workshop new posts with the help of AI)



I couldnâ€™t find much online about whatâ€™s powering this LLM. According to YouTube Help:

This tool is designed to provide answers to questions about videos youâ€™re watching. Responses are generated by large language models (LLMs). The LLMs draw on info from YouTube and the web.

Based on my brief experience with this tool, which I describe below, the LLM seems to make use of the videoâ€™s transcript and timestamps to generate answers.



In the video I was watching, the creator was making a banana cream latte in a very casual, vlog-style format (not a formal recipe vide). So, I prompted â€œgive me the recipe she uses for the banana cream latte.â€ I figure that this would be a good test for the LLMâ€™s capabilities, since the steps and ingredients for this recipe were scattered throughout the clip and not cleanly formatted.


The response was formatted as a concise, easy-to-follow recipe with timestamps accompanying each step. The abundance of timestamps was really interesting to me, and I didnâ€™t expect it. This makes me think that the results are based on a time-stamped transcript, which the LLM reads and then generates a response based on.
Overall, this response was surprisingly impressive! I verified the recipe and the LLM was able to pinpoint each of the steps, despite the person in the video occassionally going off topic and discussing things other than the recipe. This shows that the LLM was able to capture the continuity of information across a longer period of time and was not thrown off by off-topic transcriptions. Additionally, the LLM picked up on the precise wording of the creator, incorporating the brand names correctly (Monin, Nescafe) as well as nuanced measurements (â€œtiniest splashâ€).



As a YouTube viewer myself, I canâ€™t think of scenarios in which I would want to engage with this feature, as cool as it is. This is because watching videos is more of a passive activity for me â€“ I often leave YouTube videos on as Iâ€™m doing chores, eating, and getting ready for the day. During these activities, thereâ€™s not really a time when I would want to drop what Iâ€™m doing and ask the LLM a question.
However, I can definitely see the potential of this feature for tutorial and educational videos. For example, if I was viewing a math video and was having trouble understanding the concept that the instructor was writing on the screen, this feature could defintely come in handy (however, this would require it to be able to visually analyze the frames of the video and not rely solely on the transcripts). I think itâ€™s an interesting strategic push by YouTube to make viewing more immersive and interactive, and Iâ€™m excited to see how AI changes the media landscape even more in the future!

title: ChatGPT Atlas
text:
Last month, while using ChatGPT, a small pop-up appeared at the bottom of my chat window that suggested trying Atlas. Atlas is OpenAIâ€™s new AI-powered web browser (launched in October 2025) that integrates ChatGPT directly into browsing so users can ask questions, summarize pages, and perform tasks without leaving the site theyâ€™re on.
It has many features, such as: - An in-page sidebar assistant - Optional â€œbrowser memoryâ€ to recall context across sessions - A premium â€œagent modeâ€ that lets the AI take actions like filling forms or navigating websites
Overall, Atlas adds a conversational layer on top of browsing, reframing the browser as more of an an AI companion.
In this blog post, Iâ€™ll talk about my initial experience with Atlas!




After I downloaded Atlas, the first step was choosing a Chrome profile that I wanted to sync with it.

I even had the option to enable browser memory, which would give the LLM access to my search history. I thought this feature was really cool, since I can think of many uses cases for this/times when Iâ€™ve wanted to find something in my history, but the standard Chrome history search feature didnâ€™t work.
Personally, the idea of Atlas having access to my browsing history doesnâ€™t make me uncomforable, but I can image that it does for many others. Therefore, Iâ€™m glad that Atlas made this privacy option very clear, allowing users to easily opt out.





Upon cold start (first opening the app, without entering anything), I realized that I had connected Atlas to the wrong Chrome profile (whoops!). Regardless, a few things stuck out to me â€“ first, the browser retrieved my Chrome bookmarks and placed them similarly at the top of the browser screen. Additionally, the queries that it recommended seemed to be partially influenced by my ChatGPT conversation history. Iâ€™m not sure where the UPS plane crash came from (maybe trending news, but I had never had a chat with ChatGPT about this), but the other suggestions â€“ â€œInternships by companyâ€ and â€œCompare PM interview prepâ€ were definitely influenced by my chat history. These suggestions didnâ€™t seem to be based on my browser history, since I donâ€™t use this browser for internship/interview research.
In terms of UX, I really enjoyed the experience of opening this app. The interface is clean and not overwhelming, and the app even emitted some sort of color-changing glow across my desktop!



For this experiment, I wanted Atlas to help me find tarnish-resistent jewelry from the brand en route.

Similar to the ChatGPT interface, Atlas showed snippets of the modelâ€™s through process. In this screenshot, you can see it â€œthinkingâ€: > Iâ€™m thinking through how best to look for jewelry that wonâ€™t tarnish on the en route jewelry website. I need to use my capabilities wisely to find the right pieces to meet the userâ€™s needs and do a good job. Letâ€™s get started on this task!
Already, this train of thought seemed very human-like and almost agentic. By stating that it has to â€œmeet the userâ€™s needs and do a good job,â€ it seems to acknowledge that itâ€™s doing work outside the realm of a simple chat companion.

Then, it started searching online. You can see some search results that come up when it decides to search â€œEn route jewelry wonâ€™t tarnish pieces.â€ Behind the scenes, Iâ€™m guessing that my initial prompt goes through a system that produces some optimal search query for Google, which is whatâ€™s showing up here.
 Here, it seems to be scanning the website for any mention of â€œtarnish-free.â€
This was the point where I think the LLM didnâ€™t handle the query optimally. I was hoping that it would take some steps to understand what would imply a tarnish-free product (researching different mental compositions, plating, etc.) and then search for those compositions across listings (since en route lists the materials for each product).
Instead, it seemed to just scan the site for any mention of â€œtarnish-free,â€ not digging as deep as I had hoped.




For the final output, Atlas generated a correct list of products from the website that were tarnish-free. While it was able to identify these products, when I asked it to place these items in my cart, it wasnâ€™t able to. I was surprised at this, since the marketed agentic capabilities of Atlas made it seem like it should be able to.
However, this may be a specific issue with the en route website â€“ maybe adding something to a userâ€™s cart requires some sort of API on the backend that Atlas didnâ€™t have access too. This reminds me of some podcasts Iâ€™ve been listening to regarding the future of web search with the introduction of agents â€“ sites now have to be â€œAPI firstâ€ and consider not just how humans are interacting with the interface, but also agents. After playing around with Atlas, I can definitely see how important this is and Iâ€™m interested to see how this agent/site interactivity will have an impact on website interfaces and backends!

text:

title: Creating My Own AI Agent
text:
Creating My Own AI Agent


Context
Recently, Iâ€™ve been curious about agentic AI â€“ especially after seeing how companies like OpenAI and Salesforce are integrating these capabilities into their products. The whole idea felt a bit overwhelming at first, but Iâ€™ve learned that the best way for me to make sense of and get familiar with these technical concepts is just to dive in and play around with them.
In this blog post, I document my experience creating my own (very basic and simple) AI agent using Make, a site that allows you to visually create, build and automate workflows!



What is agentic AI?
Agentic AI is AI that is proactive â€“ it has agency to perform tasks by planning, acting, and sometimes proactively deciding how to reach a goal across multiple steps or tools. Generative AI, on the other hand, is more reactive â€“ it only responds to prompts given by the user.
Putting things together in Make
My experiment was simple and straightforward â€“ I wanted to pull in events from my Google Calendar, run them through AI to get notes on how I should prepare for these events, and save everything neatly into a Google Sheet.
The workflow was as follows: - Google Calendar = fetches my events - Make AI Toolkit = asks â€œwhat should I do to prepare for each event?â€ - Google Sheets = stores the answers
Make makes this process simple and visually intuitive to understand. Each circle is a module, which can draw from a wide range of apps/formats/platforms like Google Drive, JSON, OpenAI, and so on. When you add a module, you may have to give permissions (such as permission for Make to access my Google Calendar) or enter API keys (such as if you were using the OpenAI module). Modules can then be linked together to form a flow!

While the layout was extremely intuitive, I still ran into many issues throughout this process. For example, in one of my earlier iterations, I didnâ€™t have the Google Sheets module and was attempting to get the output directly from the Make AI Toolkit.
However, The way Make handles data means every calendar event comes in as a separate â€œbundle.â€ This meant I wasnâ€™t getting one nice weekly checklist; rather, I was getting ten scattered AI outputs.

So, I consulted ChatGPT for help. I fed it an image of my workflow and had it suggest solutions for me to implement. It suggested either 1) using an aggregator component after the Google Calendar to collect all event details into a single text block or 2) adding another AI component to summarize the results into one output. I wasnâ€™t able to get these recommendations to work, so I instead suggested adding a Google Sheet and asked ChatGPT where to go from there. From there, it was able to successfully instruct me how to configure this component to add each checklist as a row in a Google Sheet that lives in my personal Google Drive!
I thought this part was pretty cool â€“ I was using AI to help me build an AI agent.



The AI responses
Overall, I thought the checklists that the AI generated were pretty good! It only had the title, time, and location of my Google Calendar events to work off of. This was the response it generated for my friendâ€™s housewarming â€“ it was able to identify that â€œElliâ€ in the title was refering to someone called Elli and also understood the conventions around housewarmings (buying a gift, a possible potluck, transportation, etc.).



Next steps
This agent I created was extremely simple, so making it more complex could be a fun next project. Iâ€™m thinking about adding an AI module that parses the events, identifies ones that may require additional documents from Google Drive (notes, slideshows, etc.) or even makes them if necessary, and adds them to the spreadsheet as well!
